subject: US Market Wrap - 1st November 2019: NFP beats, ISM small miss, US/China talks constructive
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: NFP beats; ISM misses, though rises in the month; Kudlow optimistic on Phase One, Lighthizer says US/China call was constructive; China MOFCOM says also says call was constructive. Fed officials generally toe the line, encouraged by the economy.

* COMING-UP: MONDAY: Data; Australian Retail Sales; EZ Manufacturing PMI (Final); UK Construction PMI; US Factory Orders. Speakers; ECB’s Lagarde & Fed’s Daly. Earnings; Linde, Marriott, Carlsberg, Ryanair, TUESDAY: Data; Chinese Caixin Services PMI; UK Services PMI; EZ Producer Prices; Canadian Trade; US Services PMI (Final), ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (Final) & JOLTS. Events; RBA Rate Decision. Speakers; ECB’s Villeroy; Fed’s Barkin, Kaplan & Kashkari. Supply; UK & US. Earnings; Allergan, Regeneron, Telefonica, DSM, Evonik, ABF, Imperial Brands, WEDNESDAY: Data; German Industrial Orders; EZ Services PMI (Final)& Retail Sales; US Labour Costs & Productivity (Prelim). Speakers; ECB’s de Guindos & Holzmann; Fed’s Evans, Williams & Harker. Supply; US. Earnings; Qualcomm, CVS, WEC Energy, Adidas, BMW, Société Générale, Wirecard, Dialog Semiconductor, THURSDAY: Data; Australia Trade Balance; German Industrial Output; US Initial Jobless Claims & Consumer Credit. Events; BoE Rate Decision & MPR. Speakers; Fed’s Kaplan. Supply; France & US. Earnings; Walt Disney, Activision, Fox, Siemens, Deutsche Telekom, Zurich, Generali, ArcelorMittal, Telecom Italia, Lufthansa, Sainsbury’s Inmarsat. FRIDAY: Data; Swiss Unemployment; French Industrial Output; Canadian Jobs Report; Chinese Exports. Speakers; Fed’s Bostic & Brainard. Earnings; Duke Energy, Allianz, Intesa Sanpaolo, Credit Agricole, UBI Banca, Richemont.

* RANSQUAWK WEEK IN FOCUS: Click here

* RANSQUAWK CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: Click here

* US MARKET WRAP: Stocks rose to fresh record highs after the October jobs report surprised to the upside, with some encouraging internals. The ISM manufacturing survey fell short of expectations, though did rise on the month, providing some encouragement. Adding to the positive narrative were both US and China stating that the call between the two sides was constructive, and a new venue was being sought for a Phase One signing. Fed commentary in the session generally toes the line (though Kashkari unsurprisingly erred dovish), with officials encouraged by the economy and see the current stance of policy as appropriate.

* US NFP: Headline nonfarm payrolls surprised to the upside, with 128k jobs added to the economy in October against 85k expected. The net revision was +95k. The jobless rate rose by one-tenth to 3.6%, though participation also ticked up (325K workers were added to the labor force, offsetting a 241K rise in household employment). Average hourly earnings rose by 0.2% M/M, short of the 0.3% street view, though the Y/Y rate came in at 3.0% in line with the consensus. Overall the report was judged as solid. The composition of the job gains was also broad across sectors. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the strike at GM ought to have trimmed around 50k from this month's total, but jobs in the vehicle sector declined by 42k. "Still, ex-GM the payroll number would have been about 170K or so, which is respectable, and the upward revisions to August and September suggests that the trend in private payrolls ex-GM is also about 170K," Pantheon writes. However, with that said, the consultancy notes that forward-looking surveys continue to point to the trend in payroll growth slowing to only 50K or so by the turn of next year; PM acknowledges that this may be wrong, since shifts in sentiment do not always translate into shifts in action, it is not willing to assume that job gains will continue to trend at anything like 170K. Meanwhile, the wage growth figure will have disappointed some analysts, particularly after the unexpected unchanged print in September, although PM notes that two adverse calendar effects (an early survey, and a relatively long month, at 22 working days) kept a lid on the rebound, and the consultancy expects a 0.4% M/M rise in the November report.

* US ISM MANUFACTURING: At 48.3, the headline missed the expected 48.9, though did rise from the prior 47.8; ISM states that over time, a reading above 42.9 is generally consistent with growth of the overall economy. The new orders index rose to 49.1 from 47.3; prices dropped to 45.5 from a prior 49.7, against an expected rise to 49.9. Pantheon argued that the modest uptick in the headline is welcome, but the survey remains weak, consistent with falling output and capex, but not recession across the economy as a whole. "The headline index continues to underperform relative to models based on the regional PMIs and Fed surveys, probably because no regional survey covers the west coast, where the most China-dependent ports are located." PM also says that the headline remains well below the level implied by the Chinese PMIs, which can be attributed to the trade war. Looking ahead, the consultancy says that the new orders component tends to lead the other components, and as such, the October report bodes well for a further modest increase in November, all factors being equal. PM is also encouraged by the rebound in export orders (bouncing to 50.4 from 41.0 in September; "we still most of the risk to Q4 growth is to the downside, but we are much less worried now about a disaster," PM adds.

* NEC DIRECTOR KUDLOW/USTR LIGHTHIZER: NEC Director Kudlow delivered upbeat remarks; on US/China talks, he said US negotiators were very optimistic, and although the Phase One deal is not yet completed, agricultural, currency and financial services chapters are nearly done; Kudlow said enormous progress had been made on intellectual property theft issues, but it was also not quote complete; he noted some progress on forced transfer of technology, but said these elements would probably slip into Phase Two of deal. The White House advisor said that December tariffs were still on the table until Phase One is signed; US President Trump has hinted that he may be willing to look at pulling those tariffs if Phase One is completed. Domestically, Kudlow said the administration was working on 'tax cuts 2.0' for the middle-classes. On the Fed, Kudlow said monetary policy was now "fortunately" swinging into accommodative territory, adding that that there has not been a conversation to remove Fed Chair Powell. Finally, on the potential for a trade deal with the UK, Kudlow said Trump would love to do a trade deal with the UK, but are concerned over EU regulations and stipulations. USTR Lighthizer said the US and China had a constructive call today; says trade talks today were constructive and made progress in a variety of areas. China’s MOFCOM said US/China talks did achieve a consensus in principle, were constructive and they discussed the next step in trade consultations.

* FED SPEAKERS: Fed Vice Chair Clarida (voter) said the October jobs report was very solid, and the resilient economy was in a very good place, monetary policy was in a good place; however, Clarida still views the balance of risks as somewhat tilted to the downside. Nevertheless, his comments were quite positive, noting that the Fed had a favourable view of the outlook, and he reiterated the central bank's data dependency, stating that every meeting was live. On the consumer sector, Clarida did not see any 'cracks' in the US consumer, saying the sector has never been in better shape. Finally, Clarida did not see wage inflation as a concern. Fed's Kaplan (2020 Voter) said if the US consumer remained strong, the US will enjoy solid growth. Kaplan sees monetary policy now at an appropriate level, advocating a patient stance from here. Fed's Kashkari (2020 voter, dove) said monetary policy had been too tight, US economy was not at maximum employment, and inflation has been below 2%; Kashkari argued that the Fed was in a "free lunch zone" where there is no trade-off between the two mandates of employment and inflation. Fed's Rosengren (voter, hawk), explaining his hawkish dissent at this week's FOMC, said fiscal and monetary policy were already accommodative, and he added that with labour markets tight, inflation near target, real GDP growing around estimates of its potential, and a moderation of the risks surrounding trade and Brexit, further accommodation was not needed. Fed's Quarles (voter, Neutral) said the US economy was doing well, and he is optimistic about the outlook, and also the longer-term potential of the U.S. economy. Quarles said a particular source of strength has been the labour market, and he was encouraged by labour force participation, as the tight labour market has motivated workers to either join or remain in the labour force, halting, at least for the time being, a long-standing downward trend. Although the pace of job gains has slowed this year, Quarles said the Fed expected some deceleration because of how low the unemployment rate has fallen. However, he noted that one prominent factor weighing on a relatively robust domestic economy has been weak growth among our trading partners; Find the weakness of investment to be of particular concern. Fed's Williams (voter) said the economy is in a very good place and is strong.

* GEOPOLITICAL: US Secretary of State Pompeo announced the US is to impose further sanctions and nuclear curbs on Iran. The sanctions are put on the Iranian construction sector and trade restrictions on four materials used in the nation’s military or nuclear programmes. The US targeted the construction sector as it believes it is controlled (directly or indirectly) by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps who have been designated a foreign terrorist group. Elsewhere, reports suggested Yemen’s Houthi rebels shot down a US-made drone near the Saudi Arabia border; however, details were sparse, and it is not yet clear who the drone belonged to.

* CHINA CAIXIN PMI: China Caixin PMI: October’s reading surprised to the upside printing 51.7 rising from 51.4 beating expectations for a fall to 51. The data was in contrast to the prior day’s official PMI, which declined by more than expected. New orders saw its sharpest increase since January 2013, rising to 53.6 from 52.0 on improved conditions, and a recovery in customer demand. New export orders rose for the first time in five months to 51.1 from 49.1. Employment contracted even further to the lowest point since September 2018, while prices declined slightly; output prices fell further into contractionary territory, and input prices fell slightly to 51.1. Goldman Sachs highlights the particularly large diversion in October between the Caixin and official release, noting that new export orders in the Caixin data seems to slightly lead the trend in the official PMI, although survey times and different company samples could have also contributed. GS concludes that “in general, however, the NBS manufacturing PMI shows a higher correlation with hard indicators such as industrial production in recent years.”

* US/CHINA TRADE: The WTO ruled in favour of China in a dispute, approving USD 3.6bln worth of sanctions on the US, over the latter’s failure to abide by anti-dumping rules with regard to Chinese products. The arbitration relates to a complaint filed by China nearly six years ago, long predating the start of the US/China trade standoff. China originally sought over USD 7bln in retaliation. Separately, in a similar tone to White House Economic Advisor Kudlow, Commerce Secretary Ross was upbeat on the progress being made in US/China trade negotiations towards a Phase 1 deal. “Good sized transactions” are upcoming on his trip to Asia, he said, adding that he hopes the US can resurrect a date for the two countries to sign a deal around the same time it would have been signed at Chile's APEC summit. Elsewhere, the SCMP, citing a Chinese diplomatic source, reported that China will further open up its market for foreign enterprises, as Beijing and Washington are poised to sign an interim trade agreement, but the pace of reform will not be led by the United States. The observer added that China was willing to consider adjusting its state-led economic development, but added it would do so in a cautious manner.

* UK ELECTION: UK Brexit Party Leader Farage announced that his party would be fielding candidates across a large number of constituencies, contrary to speculation earlier in the week that he would focus only on a small number of Labour leave constituencies in order not to split the Brexit vote. Farage was critical of UK PM Johnson’s deal with the EU and made the PM an offer; drop the WAB, pursue no deal or a simple Free Trade Agreement and the two parties could form a non-aggression pact (meaning the Brexit Party would not field candidates against the Conservatives in certain areas). Commentators note that UK PM Johnson will almost certainly not accept the offer, preferring to campaign on the deal already agreed with the EU, but some suggested that hard-line Brexiteers within the Conservative Party may find the offer more appealing (although they would almost certainly get the boot should they refuse to back Johnson’s deal). Farage said that alliances were being discussed at a local level. Despite their healthy lead in national polls, the Brexit Party’s decision to field candidates across a large number of constituencies is a blow to the party.

* S&P 500 1% at 3067, Dow Jones  1.1% at 27346, NASDAQ-100 1% at 8161; SECTORS: Energy  2.5%, Industrials  2.2%, Materials  1.4%, Financials  1.4%, Information Technology  1.2%, Telecommunication Services  0.8%, Consumer Discretionary  0.7%, Health Care  0.2%, Consumer Staples  0%, Utilities  -0.2%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: BeiGene (BGNE) surged amid Amgen (AMGN) taking a 20.5% stake in the Chinese co. Fitbit (FIT) also surged after Alphabet (GOOGL) officially made a USD 2.1bln acquisition offer. Energy E&Ps were generally stronger as crude benchmarks traded higher on positive US-China trade rumblings. The back up in yields saw the rate-sensitive real estate sector underperform, too.

* EARNINGS: Exxon Mobil (XOM) beat EPS and Revenue estimates, whilst Chevron (CVX) missed, seeing the former open higher and the latter lower. Qorvo (QRVO), Fortinet (FTNT) and Newell (NWL) all surged after beating estimates and impressing on guidance. Pinterest (PINS) was the latest ex-tech unicorn to take a nosedive as investors became cautious on valuation following a lacklustre earnings report. Arista Networks (ANET) also tanked lower amid an ominous guidance view, seeing the stock downgraded across brokerages. Colgate-Palmolive (CL) underperformed on a revenue miss. Alibaba (BABA) reported a strong quarter but its ADR edged just modestly higher. LyondellBasell (LYB) was firmer after a profit beat and noting increased profitability moving forward under the new IMO 2020 sulphur regulations. Abbvie (ABBV) and Sempra Energy (SRE) also outperformed post strong earnings.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLES USD 2.02 HIGHER AT USD 56.20/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLES USD 2.07 HIGHER AT USD 61.69/BBL: A solid NFP report, followed optimism on the US/China trade front saw crude prices move higher on Friday. WTI Dec’ 19 reached highs of USD 56.03/bbl, and Brent Jan’ 20 USD 61.79/bbl, both breaking the highs seen on Thursday. Again, supply side factors were out of focus. Russia oil production exports from Black Sea port of Tuapse edged higher to 1.396mln tonnes in November (from 1.345mln tonnes scheduled for October), while Iraq total oil exports averaged 3.447mln BPD in October, lower than the 3.61mln BPD in September. Elsewhere, Marathon shut its Galveston Bay Texas (585k BPD) refinery's gasoline unit due to instrumentation outages, sources stated. Baker Hughes US rig count (Nov 1): oil rigs -5 at 691, natgas rigs -3 at 130, total rigs -8 at 822.

* T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 9 TICKS LOWER AT 130-00+: Treasuries pared gains and yields were higher across the curve by around 3bps, though major curve spreads were little changed at settlement, after the US employment situation report surprised to the upside, although action was still tenative ahead of the manufacturing ISM, which missed expectations, though rose versus the prior. Additionally, commentary around US/China trade has been constructive, giving hopes that the Phase One deal can be signed, while there was not much in the Fedspeak for the FI bulls, with officials generally encouraged by the state of the economy, while noting familiar risks. Combined, it might that pricing for December rate cuts lightened, with money markets implying around 12.5% chance of a cut, versus around 22% at the close of business on Thursday.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP - USD: The Greenback remains depressed, but off lows in wake of US payrolls data that comfortably beat consensus and came with an even larger back month upgrade to allay concerns about a more pronounced slowdown in the labour market and the adverse effects of GM’s strike. However, the DXY recovery has faded ahead of 97.500 within a 97.160-98.008 wtd range and the watershed or major game-changer came on Wednesday with the culmination of the Fed’s latest 2-day policy meeting. To recap, the FOMC delivered a 3rd 25 bp insurance rate cut, as almost unanimously expected, but tweaked forward guidance to imply no need to extend mid-cycle easing unless the economy fails to sustain momentum, and the first glance at Q3 GDP in the run up to the accompanying statement supported the change from ‘acting as appropriate’ to pause pending unfolding data/developments. The Dollar duly rallied, but only until the post-meeting press conference where chair Powell said that the bar to hiking is high and the subsequent miss in manufacturing ISM justifies his prognosis. Meanwhile, relatively pronounced US Treasury curve bull flattening also weighed on the Buck along with rebalancing and positioning for month end.

* NZD, AUD, CAD: The Antipodean Dollars haver spent another week playing cat and mouse, as the Aud/Nzd cross whip-sawed between 1.0825-1.0720, but the Kiwi has emerged ahead of the Aussie and its US counterpart in wake of an improvement in the NBNZ business outlook and with Westpac rolling its RNBZ rate cut projection out to February 2020 from November. Nzd/Usd is extending gains above 0.6400 and testing 0.6450, while Aud/Usd has found 0.6900 a tougher big figure to breach even though Aussie CPI was in line with forecasts and RBA rhetoric has underscored the on hold for now mantra ahead of November’s policy meeting on the premise that the economy is turning the corner. Conversely, a rather reserved/cautious assessment from the BoC with no indication about the direction of the next policy move, which was reaffirmed in the post-convene presser has undermined the Loonie with Usd/Cad currently towards the upper end of its 1.3207-1.3041 band.

* GBP, EUR: Sterling and the single currency continue to track each other alongside broad risk sentiment and the Dollar indirectly by default. However, the Pound has been a net beneficiary and outperformer on Brexit and UK political-related factors as the EU approved the latest UK request for an Article 50 extension and PM Johnson finally got Parliament backing for a December 12 election. On that note, HoC support was only secured by ‘accepting’ the Brextension until January 31 next year and conceding that the WAB and PM would not receive enough votes to be ratified in time for a shorter technical delay to the prior October 31 deadline. Nevertheless, pre-GE polls are looking more favourable for the Tories and Cable is not far from 1.2975 highs, with Eur/Gbp still knocking on the door of 0.8600 even though Eur/Usd is firmly above 1.1150.

* JPY, CHF: The Yen, Franc and Gold as the other notorious safe-haven have all made strides over the course of the week, and mainly due to jitters about the US and China building on the framework of trade deal Phase 1 given Beijing’s scepticism about the sincerity of President Trump and his Washington representatives, reluctance to implement big structural reforms and demand that the US remove all tariffs before negotiations move to the next stage. From the US perspective, including POTUS, NEC boss Kudlow and even Trade Advisor Navarro, talks are progressing well and on track for Trump and his Chinese peer to sign off around the middle of the month regardless of the Chile APEC being cancelled. However, the markets appear unconvinced with Usd/Jpy hugging 108.00, Usd/Chf keeping tabs on 0.9850 and Xau/Usd back over Usd1500/oz. Note, the BoJ refined rate guidance and removed time targets for reaching its inflation mandate in favour of attaining the actual level in keeping with the new enhanced ECB guidance, while SNB President Jordan repeated the importance of NIRP and direct intervention just ahead of unexpectedly deflationary Swiss CPI data.

* NOK, SEK: Some respite for the Scandi Crowns on technical grounds and a significant pick up in Norway’s manufacturing PMI vs steeper Swedish contraction that is highly unlikely to deter the Riksbank from its determination to raise the repo one more time in December before taking a break from policy normalisation. Eur/Nok is back around 10.1500 vs 10.3100+ record highs, while Eur/Sek has piggy-backed to a degree from 10.7700 towards 10.6700 notwithstanding a bounce in Nok/Sek from recent lows.

* EM: Busy week for regional currencies on the wider themes, impulses and factors influencing sentiment and direction, but also in their own right given another 50 bp easing from the BCB, capital controls in Argentina, the eagerly awaited Eskom skewed SA MTBS and post-CBRT meeting releases in Turkey alongside the military manoeuvres in Syria after the official ceasefire. In short, the Brl, Try and Ars are all paring losses, but Zar to a lesser extent given ongoing investor angst over bleak budget projections and not as much assistance for the ailing utility as anticipated, while Moody’s is set to deliver its ratings verdict and the agency seems primed cut downgrade the outlook if not standing to junk.

Weekly FX Wrap: NFP rescues Dollar from worse post-FOMC (and ISM) fate
content:
USD

The Greenback remains depressed, but off lows in wake of US payrolls data that comfortably beat consensus and came with an even larger back month upgrade to allay concerns about a more pronounced slowdown in the labour market and the adverse effects of GM’s strike. However, the DXY recovery has faded ahead of 97.500 within a 97.160-98.008 wtd range and the watershed or major game-changer came on Wednesday with the culmination of the Fed’s latest 2-day policy meeting. To recap, the FOMC delivered a 3rd 25 bp insurance rate cut, as almost unanimously expected, but tweaked forward guidance to imply no need to extend mid-cycle easing unless the economy fails to sustain momentum, and the first glance at Q3 GDP in the run up to the accompanying statement supported the change from ‘acting as appropriate’ to pause pending unfolding data/developments. The Dollar duly rallied, but only until the post-meeting press conference where chair Powell said that the bar to hiking is high and the subsequent miss in manufacturing ISM justifies his prognosis. Meanwhile, relatively pronounced US Treasury curve bull flattening also weighed on the Buck along with rebalancing and positioning for month end.

NZD/AUD/CAD

Conversely, a rather reserved/cautious assessment from the BoC with no indication about the direction of the next policy move, which was reaffirmed in the post-convene presser has undermined the Loonie with Usd/Cad currently towards the upper end of its 1.3207-1.3041 band.

GBP/EUR 

Sterling and the single currency continue to track each other alongside broad risk sentiment and the Dollar indirectly by default. However, the Pound has been a net beneficiary and outperformer on Brexit and UK political-related factors as the EU approved the latest UK request for an Article 50 extension and PM Johnson finally got Parliament backing for a December 12 election. On that note, HoC support was only secured by ‘accepting’ the Brextension until January 31 next year and conceding that the WAB and PM would not receive enough votes to be ratified in time for a shorter technical delay to the prior October 31 deadline. Nevertheless, pre-GE polls are looking more favourable for the Tories and Cable is not far from 1.2975 highs, with Eur/Gbp still knocking on the door of 0.8600 even though Eur/Usd is firmly above 1.1150.

JPY/CHF

The Yen, Franc and Gold as the other notorious safe-haven have all made strides over the course of the week, and mainly due to jitters about the US and China building on the framework of trade deal Phase 1 given Beijing’s scepticism about the sincerity of President Trump and his Washington representatives, reluctance to implement big structural reforms and demand that the US remove all tariffs before negotiations move to the next stage. From the US perspective, including POTUS, NEC boss Kudlow and even Trade Advisor Navarro, talks are progressing well and on track for Trump and his Chinese peer to sign off around the middle of the month regardless of the Chile APEC being cancelled. However, the markets appear unconvinced with Usd/Jpy hugging 108.00, Usd/Chf keeping tabs on 0.9850 and Xau/Usd back over Usd1500/oz. Note, the BoJ refined rate guidance and removed time targets for reaching its inflation mandate in favour of attaining the actual level in keeping with the new enhanced ECB guidance, while SNB President Jordan repeated the importance of NIRP and direct intervention just ahead of unexpectedly deflationary Swiss CPI data.

NOK/SEK

Some respite for the Scandi Crowns on technical grounds and a significant pick up in Norway’s manufacturing PMI vs steeper Swedish contraction that is highly unlikely to deter the Riksbank from its determination to raise the repo one more time in December before taking a break from policy normalisation. Eur/Nok is back around 10.1500 vs 10.3100+ record highs, while Eur/Sek has piggy-backed to a degree from 10.7700 towards 10.6700 notwithstanding a bounce in Nok/Sek from recent lows.

EM

Busy week for regional currencies on the wider themes, impulses and factors influencing sentiment and direction, but also in their own right given another 50 bp easing from the BCB, capital controls in Argentina, the eagerly awaited Eskom skewed SA MTBS and post-CBRT meeting releases in Turkey alongside the military manoeuvres in Syria after the official ceasefire. In short, the Brl, Try and Ars are all paring losses, but Zar to a lesser extent given ongoing investor angst over bleak budget projections and not as much assistance for the ailing utility as anticipated, while Moody’s is set to deliver its ratings verdict and the agency seems primed cut downgrade the outlook if not standing to junk.

  • European Cash indices are a touch firmer but little changed as markets await the US Jobs report
  • Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI beat Exp.; foreign ministry says reports of a US/China leaders meeting in Macau is speculation
  • US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to impose new sanctions and nuclear curbs on Iran
  • FX complex is little changed overall vs. a slightly softer USD
  • Looking ahead highlights include US Labour Market Report, Construction Spending and ISM; Fed’s Clarida, Williams, Quarles, Kaplan & Daly
  • Earnings: Exxon Mobil, Berkshire Hathaway, Abbvie, Chevron

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets mostly staged a turnaround of the weak lead from Wall St. where sentiment was dampened after mixed trade rhetoric stoked further US-China uncertainty and with participants tentative ahead of US NFP data, although risk appetite has somewhat improved with the help of encouraging Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was relatively flat as resilience in commodity related stocks just about offset the continued underperformance in the largest weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) lagged and suffered the ill effects of the currency-risk dynamic. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were initially weighed by a substantial weekly liquidity drain and after reports suggested that China had doubts about the possibility of a long-term trade deal with US President Trump amid concerns of his impulsive nature, although Chinese bourses later recovered following better than expected Chinese Caixin PMI data which matched its highest since February 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs extended on the prior day’s rally following recent comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who continued to stress the possibility for lower rates, while prices were also supported amid underperformance of Japanese stocks and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 350bln in 5yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 590bln vs. Prev. CNY 560bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0437 (Prev. 7.0533)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Oct) 51.7 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 51.4). (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry says the reports of a Chinese/US leaders meeting in Macau is speculation. (Newswires)

Japan and China are considering signing a ‘fifth political document’ during Chinese President Xi visit to Japan in Spring 2020., according to Nikkei citing sources. (Nikkei)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to impose new sanctions and nuclear curbs on Iran. (Newswires)

Yemen's Houthi's have reportedly downed a US-made drone near the border with Saudi., Sputnik. (Twitter)

UK/EU

Brexit Party leader Farage refused to rule out the prospect of his party withdrawing candidates from hundreds of seats in the upcoming elections. (Sky News)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Oct) 49.6 vs. Exp. 48.1 (Prev. 48.3). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses are slightly firmer (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%) with the region buoyed by encouraging Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI which helped boost sentiment during APAC hours. Trade this morning has been tentative as is usually the case ahead of the US labour market report, with some gains handed back ahead of the release with US ISM Manufacturing PMI also on the docket. Sector performance is reflective of an improved risk tone; Tech (+0.7%), Energy (+0.7%), Materials (+0.5%), Industrials (+0.7%) and Consumer Discretionary (+0.7%) are all firmer, while Utilities (-0.3%), Consumer Staple (+0.3%) and Health Care (+0.1%) lag. Financials (U/C) are also lower; yields have broadly failed to recover since yesterday’s downbeat Chicago PMI and post-FOMC, while stock specific news in the form Danske Bank’s (-3.1%) earnings could also being weighing, after the Co. narrowed its FY19 net outlook to the lower end of range with further potential downside as the Russian Central Bank revoked the Co.’s license for its Russian unit. Elsewhere, stock specifics; DSV (+7.5%) shares are bid after solid earnings. Elsewhere, better than expected results from US Steel (X) is giving a boost to ThyssenKrupp (+1.6%) and Salzgitter (+0.5%). Softer earnings also see Aker ASA (-4.2%) shares under pressure, while Fiat Chrysler (+1.6%) opened lower amid ongoing protestation from various labour unions against the Co.’s proposed merger with Peugeot (+3.3%).

Goldman Sachs (GS) estimates upper end of reasonably possible aggregate legal loss of approx USD 2.9bln in September-quarter (vs USD 2.6bln at end of June-quarter). (Newswires) Co. are 6% lower in pre-market trade.

Apple (AAPL) may invest directly in Japan Display (6740 JT), according to reports. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The DXY seems to have stabilised after its post-FOMC reversal, with the index holding above the 97.000 level in a confined 97.162-348 range and the restrained trade reflecting the overall tone that often pans out in the run up to US labour data. Indeed, Usd/major pairings and even Dollar/EMs are relatively quiet and contained bar the odd exception.

G10 - As noted above, not much deviation across the board even though data and manufacturing PMIs have thrown up some surprises, like the more encouraging Chinese Caixin survey overnight. The Kiwi continues to outperform and sits firmer on the 0.6400 handle vs its US counterpart, while the Aussie appears wary about hefty option expiries at the 0.6900 strike and with the Aud/Nzd cross capped at 1.0750. Elsewhere, Cable only got a brief/modest lift from a significant UK PMI beat as sub-components were less upbeat and Brexit stock-piling flattered the headline number. Note also, expiry interest resides close by (1.1 bn at 1.2950) and 0.8600 is still proving impenetrable in Eur/Gbp pending the looming Brexit Party pre-election conference, as Eur/Usd remains solid around 1.1150 where a massive 3.1 bn expiries reside. Meanwhile, the Loonie remains rooted to 1.3150 and Franc is pretty resilient between 0.9855-75 and around 1.1000 vs the single currency amidst very mixed Swiss macro releases (CPI back in deflation, but retail sales and manufacturing PMI recovering quite well). Conversely, Scandi PMIs diverged further to provide some respite for the Norwegian Krona vs its Swedish peer and the Euro, as Eur/Nok tests 10.2000 vs Eur/Sek sticky above 10.7000.

EM - Contrasting fortunes for the Lira and Rand, as the former felt the weight of a bleak Turkish manufacturing PMI, but the latter took comfort from a decent improvement in SA (though still sub-50) awaiting Moody’s ratings review.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1100 (1.2BLN), 1.1150 (3.1BLN), 1.1175-80 (800M), 1.1200 (5.3BLN)

- GBP/USD: 1.2900 (2.4BLN), 1.2950 (1.1BLN)

- EUR/GBP: 0.8600 (570M)

- AUD/USD: 0.6870 (370M), 0.6900 (1.4BLN), 0.6915 (400M)

FIXED INCOME

Gilts have slipped to a minor new Liffe low at 132.62 (-22 ticks and 30 ticks off best levels) in wake of the UK manufacturing survey even though premature pre-October 31 stocking inflated the headline print and may now unwind given the latest Brextension. However, UK bonds may get another pre-NFP jolt via political impulses and news about the Brexit Party’s election strategy that might see candidates pulled for tactical reasons. Elsewhere, playing ranges and keeping powder dry for the big US releases and raft of post-FOMC Fed speakers remains prevalent for Bunds and US Treasuries, albeit latter after some big block trades in futures and options during the overnight session.

COMMODITIES                                      

Crude markets are treading water with little in the way of significant price action to report after the complex benefitted from the tailwind of firmer than expected Chinese PMI data. In fitting with market’s broader tentative feel, ranges are thin ahead of key today’s US data. For now, WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’20 contracts are consolidating around the USD 54.50/bbl and USD 59.90/bbl marks respectively. US Secretary of State Pompeo stated that the US is to impose further Iranian sanctions and nuclear curbs. Metals are similarly tentative ahead of headline US data; gold is holding onto yesterday’s gains, despite a recovery in risk appetite, and is rangebound around the USD 1510/oz mark for now. Meanwhile, Copper has stabilised after yesterday’s steep declines but been unable to garner significant impetus on the back of promising Chinese data. “The more downbeat sentiment came from China’s power sector” notes ING, “which is a key area for copper consumption”. Investment in power network infrastructure over the first nine months of 2019 declined 12.5% Y/Y, according to the Chinese Electricity Council.

CME raised NatGas Henry Hub December 2019 futures margins by 11.4% to USD 2450 per contract. (Newswires)

Sempra Energy (SRE) Q3 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.50 (exp. 1.47), Revenue 2.758bln (exp. 2.94bln). Raise FY19 EPS guidance.

subject: RANsquawk Ad-Hoc Economic Analysis - PREVIEW: Nonfarm Payrolls (Oct 2019) to be released at 1230GMT/0830 EDT on 1st November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

The headline is expected at 89k, influenced by strikes at GM which might have affected 80k workers; the trend rate has held steady in recent months, though recent prints are some way off the 12-month pace. Labour market indicators have been mixed: the ADP surveyed mixed expectations, and the previous was revised down; initial jobless claims have moved horizontally; job cuts announcements rose; the ISM surveys have not been released, but the Markit PMI saw the employment sub-index fall at the steepest rate since 2009; consumer confidence signals were also mixed, with the differential between jobs “plentiful” and “hard to get” widening, boding well, and consumers’ expectations for an income prospects rose; but consumers were less confident about the outlook and the expectation for more jobs in the months ahead fell.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures lag awaiting UK PMI, Brexit Party news and NFP
content: Gilts returned to Liffe mostly on the back foot and underperforming core counterparts between 132.66-83 parameters vs their previous 132.84 settlement, with Short Sterling contracts also defensive and 1-2.5 ticks adrift at one stage. Some unwinding of the month end bid kept apparent in early trade, but the 10 year bond has regrouped more recently to probe above parity, albeit still lagging behind Bunds that have been up to 171.99 (+23 ticks vs +8 ticks for the UK benchmark at 132.92 before topping out again). Manufacturing PMI on the domestic agenda, but probably overshadowed by any salient announcement from the Brexit Party around 10.30GMT and certainly on the undercard in terms of Friday’s US releases in the form of jobs data and the manufacturing ISM.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets mostly staged a turnaround from the weak Wall St. lead, China outperformed whilst Nikkei 225 lagged
  • In FX, USD held onto recent losses, JPY was marginally firmer, antipodeans welcomed above-forecast China Caixin Manufacturing PMI
  • US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to impose new sanctions and nuclear curbs on Iran
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swiss CPI, UK Manufacturing PMI, US Labour Market Report, Construction Spending and ISM Manufacturing PMI, Moody's on South Africa, Fed's Williams, Clarida, Quarles, Daly and Kaplan
  • Earnings include Exxon Mobil, Berkshire Hathaway, Abbvie, Chevron, Danske Bank

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets mostly staged a turnaround of the weak lead from Wall St. where sentiment was dampened after mixed trade rhetoric stoked further US-China uncertainty and with participants tentative ahead of US NFP data, although risk appetite has somewhat improved with the help of encouraging Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was relatively flat as resilience in commodity related stocks just about offset the continued underperformance in the largest weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) lagged and suffered the ill effects of the currency-risk dynamic. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were initially weighed by a substantial weekly liquidity drain and after reports suggested that China had doubts about the possibility of a long-term trade deal with US President Trump amid concerns of his impulsive nature, although Chinese bourses later recovered following better than expected Chinese Caixin PMI data which matched its highest since February 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs extended on the prior day’s rally following recent comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who continued to stress the possibility for lower rates, while prices were also supported amid underperformance of Japanese stocks and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 350bln in 5yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 590bln vs. Prev. CNY 560bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0437 (Prev. 7.0533)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Oct) 51.7 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 51.4). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Brexit Party leader Farage refused to rule out the prospect of his party withdrawing candidates from hundreds of seats in the upcoming elections. (Sky News)

US President Trump said under some Brexit circumstances, the US would be precluded from doing a trade deal with the UK and would not involve the UK national health service in a potential trade deal, while he added trade between the UK and US could be four to five times higher than it currently is under a trade deal. (Newswires)

Former BoE Deputy Governor Shafik is the current UK government's preferred candidate for BoE Governor, according to a BBC reporter. (BBC/Twitter)

 

FX

In FX markets, the USD remained near post-FOMC lows as the latest data provided the currency no favours in which Chicago PMI slipped to its weakest since December 2015, while the looming US NFP jobs data also kept price action in limbo. The greenback’s major counterparts eked mild gains with EUR/USD back above 1.1150 and GBP/USD breached 1.2950 but with upside limited amid substantial option expiries of EUR 3.4bln and GBP 1.1bln at the aforementioned levels respectively. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were initially pressured alongside the trade uncertainty although have partially nursed losses in the aftermath of the Chinese PMI data, and antipodeans also welcomed the strong Chinese data coupled with a firmer CNY reference rate setting.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with oil prices driven by risk sentiment in which WTI crude futures recouped some of the prior day’s heftier losses with the overnight rebound spurred after better than expected Chinese PMI data, while on the geopolitical front, US Secretary of State Pompeo also announced the US is to impose further Iran sanctions. Elsewhere, gold held on to the prior session’s gains on the back of a weaker USD although prices have plateaued overnight heading into the key US jobs data, while the gradual improvement in risk tone spurred some short covering for copper. CME raised NatGas Henry Hub December 2019 futures margins by 11.4% to USD 2450 per contract. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to impose new sanctions and nuclear curbs on Iran. (Newswires)

 

US

The TPLEX sang to the tune of risk appetite, making gains throughout the day as equity bourses moved lower on revived US-China trade deal caution. Sellers found little reprieve as data also supported the haven bid, with a surprise multi-year low in the Chicago PMI and the Core PCE Price Index showed downward pricing pressures. Positioning was also likely to be supportive for the debt complex, with month end factors and an expected volatile NFP report on Friday. By settlement the entire yield curve was lower by approximately 10bps. T-note futures (Z9) settled 26 ticks higher at 130-09+.

White House officials have reportedly ramped up their push for a new tax cut plan led by NEC Director Kudlow to try set up a sharper contrast with 2020 Democrats. (Washington Post)

White House named Thomas Storch as new Senior Trade Adviser on the National Economic Council and it was also reported that US President Trump is to nominate US envoy to North Korea Biegun as Deputy Secretary of State. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (Unch.) is flat with resilience in commodity related stocks just about offsetting the continued underperformance in the largest weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) lags and suffers the ill effects of the currency-risk dynamic. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were initially weighed by a substantial weekly liquidity drain and after reports suggested that China had doubts about the possibility of a long-term trade deal with US President Trump amid concerns of his impulsive nature, although Chinese bourses have since recovered following better than expected Chinese Caixin PMI data which matched its highest since February 2017.

In FX markets, the USD remains near its post-FOMC lows with the latest data providing the currency no favours as Chicago PMI slipped to its weakest since December 2015, while the looming US NFP jobs data also keeps price action in limbo. The greenback’s major counterparts have eked mild gains with EUR/USD back above 1.1150 and GBP/USD breaching 1.2950 but with upside limited amid substantial option expiries of EUR 3.4bln and GBP 1.1bln respectively at the aforementioned levels. Trade

US President Trump tweeted that China and the USA are working on selecting a new site for signing of Phase 1 of the trade agreement which is around 60% of total deal and a new location will be announced soon, while Trump added he and Chinese President Xi will do the signing. In related news, NEC Director Kudlow said US-China talks are going smoothly, according to a White House aide. (Newswires)

China is said to be doubtful about the possibility of a long-term trade deal with US President Trump, while they are said to be unwilling to budge on big structural changes and demand an end to tariffs for any Phase 2 talks. Furthermore, China is reportedly concerned about US President Trump’s "impulsive nature" and the risk he may back out of the Phase 1 deal that both sides say they want to sign in the coming weeks. (Newswires)

China said it will not sit back if the US were to deploy intermediate range missiles in Asia amid Beijing accusations the US is trying to gain military advantage by pulling out of Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. (SCMP)
